title-group.article-title: A Case of Anthracofibrosis Presenting with Paratracheal Mass Compressing Trachea

body.p: Anthracosis is a black pigment discoloration located mainly in the bronchi because of the inhalation of dust or particulates.1 Anthracofibrosis is defined as narrowing or obliteration of the bronchial lumen associated with black pigmentation of the overlying mucosa.1 Anthracofibrosis often presents in pulmonary form. Extrathoracic anthracofibrosis is very rare, and paratracheal anthracofibrosis has not been reported to the best of our knowledge. Paratracheal anthracofibrosis could compress the trachea, mimicking malignancy.

An 80-year-old man presented with a 1-month history of cough, sputum, and mild dyspnea. The patient had a 10-year history of diabetes and hypertension and a medical history of pulmonary tuberculosis and had received antituberculous therapy several decades ago. The patient had stopped smoking 40 years earlier (1.5 pack-years). The patient denied weight loss, hemoptysis, night sweats, or anorexia. Flexible laryngoscopy revealed a 2-cm protruding portion of the right trachea with intact mucosa, suggestive of a submucosal tumor. Neck computed tomography (CT) with enhancement showed a 2.3- × 1.9-cm ill-defined, subtle, enhancing soft-tissue lesion that compressed the trachea in the right paratracheal area. It was interpreted as a suspected malignancy. F-18 fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) positron emission tomography(PET)/CT demonstrated a corresponding hypermetabolic focus in favor of a malignancy with maximal standardized uptake value (SUVmax) of 5.7 (Figure 1). Cicatrical change and paracicatrical small nodules in the right upper and middle lobes of the lung were observed with an SUVmax of 4.1, suggesting old inflammatory change. Bronchoscopic examination revealed anthracotic pigmentation of the bronchial mucosa and narrowing of the bronchial lumin, predominantly in the right upper lobe. The patient did not have an occupational history associated with exposure to coal dust or other soot particles. Bronchial brushings were negative for malignancy. Sputum and bronchial aspirates were negative in smear and culture for Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The patient had no suspected malignant lesion in thyroid ultrasonography, esophagoscopy, and chest CT. The patient underwent a transcervical open biopsy of the paratracheal mass. The mass was a black fibrous hard lesion with severe adhesion between carotid artery and trachea (Figure 2). Histopathological examination of the biopsy sample revealed anthracofibrosis with no evidence of neoplasia. The patient had an uneventful postoperative recovery. Symptoms disappeared after supportive medical treatment, and the patient remained symptom-free during a 6-month follow-up.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Anthracofibrosis is a bronchoscopic finding showing dark anthracotic pigmentation on the bronchial mucosa in conjunction with bronchial narrowing or obliteration.1 Most patients with bronchial anthracofibrosis have had no exposure to mining or industry and no history of heavy smoking. However, a potential relationship with tuberculosis has been suggested.1 Our patient also had a history of old pulmonary tuberculosis without exposure to heavy smoking and air pollution.

Anthracofibrosis often causes intrapulmonary lymphadenopathy, but it only very rarely causes mediastinal or axillary lymphadenopathy.2,3 Esophageal anthrocosis with mediastinal tuberculous lymphadenitis has been reported.4 Our patient presented with a paratracheal mass. Paratracheal mass can be a presentation of a malignant condition such as metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma, lung cancer, esophageal cancer, and lymphoma. Infectious conditions such as tuberculosis and granulomatous disease such as sarcoidosis are included in the differential diagnosis of paratracheal mass. In our case, sputum and bronchial aspirates were negative for tuberculosis. The patient’s radiologic finding of tracheal compression with irregular margin and hypermetabolism in F-18 FDG PET/CT was highly suspicious of malignancy. Onitilo et al2 described that mediastinal anthracosis can be a cause of false-positive F-18 FDG PET/CT. Our case is the first report of false- positive F-18 FDG PET/CT in a paratracheal mass due to anthracofibrosis. This case highlights that anthracofibrosis should be included in the differential diagnosis of FDG-avid paratracheal mass, especially in a patient with bronchial anthracofibrosis and old pulmonary tuberculosis.

Evaluation of a lower paratracheal mass has a challenging diagnostic dilemma. Varghese et al5 described endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS)–guided fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB) findings of a mediastinal anthracosis. We considered both transcervical ultrasonography–guided FNAB and EUS-guided FNAB for the histologic diagnosis of the paratracheal mass, but the approach failed because of insufficient visualization. Transcervical open biopsy provided the confirmative diagnosis of anthracofibrosis. However, we should consider open biopsy as the second diagnostic choice because of its invasiveness and the possibility of malignancy.
